choices.text: Weber test - lateralized to the better ear in sensorineural deafness
Lateralisation of sound in the Weber test with a tuning fork of 512 Hz implies a conductive loss of 15-25 dB in the ipsilateral ear
Negative Rinne test indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15-20 dB
A Rinne negative for all three tuning forks of 256, 512 & 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 30-45 dB

questions.text: All are true about the tuning fork test in hearing loss except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A Rinne negative for all three tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 45-60 dB.

A negative Rinne for 256, 512 and 1024 Hz indicates a minimum AB gap of 15, 30, and 45 dB, respectively.

Rinne's Test:

  • In this test air conduction of the ear is compared with its bone conduction.
  • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient's mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, AC is more than BC.
  • Alternatively, the patient is asked to compare the loudness of sound heard through air and bone conduction.
  • The Rinne test is called positive when AC is longer or louder than BC. It is seen in normal persons or those having sensorial deafness. A negative Rinne(BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness.
  • A negative Rinne indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15-20 dB.

False Negative Rinne:

  • It is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. The patient does not perceive any sound of the tuning fork by air conduction, but responds to bone conduction testing. This response to bone conduction is, in reality, from the opposite ear because of transcranial transmission of sound.
  • In such cases, correct diagnosis can be made by masking the non-test ear with Barany's noise box while testing for bone conduction. The Weber test will further help as it gets lateralized to the better ear.

Weber's Test:

  • In this test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.
  • Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.
  • In the Weber test, sound travels directly to the cochlea via bone. Lateralisation of sound in the Weber test with a tuning fork of 512 Hz implies a conductive loss of 15-25 dB in the ipsilateral ear or a sensorineural loss in the contralateral ear.

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test:

  • Bone conduction is a measure of cochlear function. In the ABC test, the patient's bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner (presuming that the examiner has normal hearing). The external auditory meatus of both the patient and examiner should be occluded (by pressing the tragus inwards) to prevent ambient noise from entering through the AC route.
  • In conductive deafness, the patient and the examiner hear the fork for the same duration of time. In sensorineural deafness, the patient hears the fork for a shorter duration.

questions.text: A patient presents to your clinic for evaluation of defective hearing. Rinnie's test shows air conduction greater than the bone conduction on both sides, with the Weber test lateralized to the right ear. What is the next logical step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rinne's test shows AC > BC bilaterally, suggestive of normal or sensorineural hearing loss.

Weber is lateralized to the right, meaning:

  • Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear.
  • Or conductive hearing loss in the right ear - but Rinne is positive (AC > BC), which goes against conductive loss.

Schwabach test:

Compares the patient's bone conduction to the examiner's. This helps differentiate sensorineural vs normal vs conductive loss.

  • Sensorineural: Schwabach shortened (the patient hears bone conduction shorter than the examiner).
  • Conductive: Schwabach prolonged.
  • So, the Schwabach test would help confirm sensorineural hearing loss.

Explanation of other options:

This is indicative of Normal hearing (Option A): Incorrect, because Weber lateralizing to the right suggests an abnormality.

Repeat Rinne's on right(Option C): Unnecessary, because it already shows AC > BC.

Gelle's test(Option D): Used for ossicular chain mobility (otosclerosis), not appropriate here.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with a suspected diagnosis of suppurative labyrinthitis. A positive Rinne test and a positive fistula sign were recorded on initial examination. The patient refused treatment and returned to the emergency department after 2 weeks, complaining of deafness in the same ear. On examination, the fistula sign was found to be negative. What would be the expected finding on repeating the Rinne test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient had earlier had a labyrinthine fistula. Because of no treatment, he developed a dead labyrinth.
  • A negative fistula sign in this case indicates a dead labyrinth, which implies severe sensorineural hearing loss. In such cases, a false negative Rinne's test is most likely.

False Negative Rinne:

  • It is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing. The patient does not perceive any sound of the tuning fork by air conduction, but responds to bone conduction testing. This response to bone conduction is, in reality, from the opposite ear because of transcranial transmission of sound.
  • In such cases, correct diagnosis can be made by masking the non-test ear with Barany's noise box while testing for bone conduction. The Weber test will further help as it gets lateralized to the better ear.

Explanation of other options:

True-positive Rinne(Option A): AC > BC; normal or sensorineural. Unlikely that deafness develops if there is sensorineural loss.

True-negative Rinne(Option B): BC > AC; conductive hearing loss, Unlikely because the hearing loss is now sensorineural, not conductive.

False-positive Rinne(Option C): False positive means the test shows AC > BC when there is conductive loss. In the above case, it is unilateral severe SNHL.

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this test air conduction of the ear is compared with its bone conduction. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient's mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, AC is more than BC.
  • Alternatively, the patient is asked to compare the loudness of sound heard through air and bone conduction. The Rinne test is called positive when AC is longer or louder than BC. It is seen in normal persons or those having sensorial deafness.
  • Sensorineural hearing loss associated with the physiological ageing process in the ear is called presbycusis, thus having a positive Rinne test.
  • Wax occlusion, Chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis cause conductive hearing loss, leading to negative Rinne. (Other options ruled out),

questions.text: The Patient has the complaint of right-sided hearing loss, and left ear hearing is normal. Tuning fork tests show that Rinne is Negative on the right side and positive on the left side. The Weber test is lateralized towards the right ear. The absolute bone conduction(ABC) test is normal on both sides. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Right-sided negative Rinne suggests of either conductive hearing loss on the same side or severe sensorineural hearing loss on the same side.
  • Weber's is lateralised to the right, suggestive of conductive hearing loss in the right ear.

Rinne's Test:

It is a comparison of air conduction and bone conduction.

Weber's Test:

Place the tuning fork at the centre of the head and ask the patient where the sound is heard.

questions.text: The best description of Gelle's test
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gelle's test:

  • Compares the intensity of bone-conducted tuning fork sound, without and with, raising pressure on the tympanic membrane with Siegel's speculum.
  • Normally, Gelle's test is positive because the intensity of hearing decreases when air pressure is raised in the external auditory canal(Option B ruled out).
  • In ossicular fixation or ossicular discontinuity, increased air pressure makes no changes in the sound intensity(Gelle's negative)(Option C and D ruled out).

questions.text: All are true about retrocochlear hearing loss except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retrocochlear hearing loss:

  • Recruitment is absent. Recruitment is defined as the abnormal perception of loudness. It is a feature of cochlear deafness(Meniere's disease and presbycusis).
  • Tone decay occurs quickly (> 25 dB)(Option A ruled out), due to neural adaptation.
  • Rollover phenomenon (speech discrimination worsens at higher intensity) is a notable feature(Option C ruled out)..
  • Speech discrimination is disproportionately poor(Option D ruled out) relative to pure-tone thresholds.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has become aware of increasing bilateral hearing loss. Her eardrums are normal. Her hearing tests show: Rinne test is negative on both sides, and BC-normal on both sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rinne negative on both sides, suggestive of bilateral conductive hearing loss and eardrums normal, suggestive of Otosclerosis.
  • In Tubotympanic CSOM, the eardrums are not normal(Option B ruled out).
  • In Meniere's disease, the main symptoms are vertigo and SNHL. Acoustic neuroma is also associated with SNHL(Option A and C ruled out).

Otosclerosis(Early stages):

  • It is a fixation of the footplate of the tapes. (Piston-like movement is slowed)
  • It is a disease of the optic capsule. (Bony labyrinth)
  • In otosclerosis, the dense endochondral bone of the tic membrane is replaced by spongy bone (woven bone), which is later replaced by more mature bone.
  • The histopathology picture is called Blue Mantells.
  • It is more common in females (young), mostly 2nd& 3rd decades
  • Mostly Bilateral
  • Genetic disease Autosomal Dominant(Involves genes encoding type I collagen. It is a gradually progressive disease, but Pregnancy aggravates it.
  • The most common site of origin is FISSULA ANTE FENESTRAM. It is a point anterior to the oval window.
  • The initial stage of the disease is pink in colour; this stage is called otospongiosis. It gradually turns White (this stage is called otosclerosis).
  • In the next few years, the disease will surround the footplate from all around.
  • Measles viral infection may initiate the conversion of dense bone to spongy bone. (A hypothesis only)
  • Rarely, otosclerosis can also involve the cochlea, which will lead to cochlear otosclerosis. This will lead to mixed hearing loss (CHL+SNHL). CT scan of cochlear otosclerosis shows DOUBLE RING SIGN.

Clinical Picture:

  • A young female with bilateral, gradually progressive CHL

Other symptoms-

  • Patients hear better in a noisy area; this is called Paracusis Willisii.
  • Low tone voice.
  • +/- Tinnitus (ringing sensation in the ear).

Examination:

  • 90% of patients show a normal Tympanic Membrane.
  • 10% of patients show the Schwartz sign
  • Schwartz's sign is in the Early stages. It is a Flamingo pink appearance behind the tympanic membrane.

Investigations:

  • PTA CHL+ Carhart's Notch (dip at 2000Hz in BC).
  • Tympanometry shows a Type A curve.
  • Absent stapedial reflex.

Treatment:

The Rx of choice is surgery called Stapedotomy>Stapedectomy.

Other treatments for Otosclerosis:

  • A hearing aid is given to patients unwilling to undergo surgery.
  • Sodium fluoride (NaF) oral therapy. It is the treatment of choice for:
    1. Schwartz sign (+) patient. (Early stage of disease)
    2. Cochlear otosclerosis.

NaF leads to stabilisation of the disease.
